learning_outcomes.description: Illustrate the processes by which the solid-phase regulates the availability of nutrients/toxins in the soil solution.
Explain the importance of biological organisms in cycling nutrients in soil.
Illustrate the importance of the physical properties of the soil (such as texture, structure and water holding capacity) for the growth of plants.
Evaluate the major problems facing Soil Scientists in Australia and throughout the world (such as salinity and acidity) by applying the underlying theory gained through the course.
Demonstrate core practical skills in Soil Science using laboratory and glasshouse techniques.
Solve a range of soil science problems, both individually and as part of a team.

assessments.task_description:
The practical exercise is a major part of this Course, and the written reports you prepare will draw upon what you do in the practical, but also what you have learned in the lectures and from your own reading. The practical component is worth 35% of the course total.

For the practicals, the class will be split into groups of 3-5 people. Students will have the opportunity to select their own groups.

Full task descriptions, including the assessment rubrics, are available on BlackBoard.

Report 1: Soil carbon

This report will be written and submitted individually.

Your report should follow this basic outline:

  1. Introduction (1-2 paragraphs, exclude from word count)
  2. Results and discussion (or individual 'Results’ and ‘Discussion’ sections)
  3. Conclusions
  4. References (exclude from word count)

Do not cite your Course notes (for example, LAND2003 or LAND3005). Rather, only cite articles and books from the scientific literature.

Report 2: Water Use by Plants

This practical report is completed as a group. How the workload is divided amongst your group is up to each group to decide. In this Practical Report, you need to focus on Water related practical exercises (Lysimeters, Aggregates, Hydraulic Conductivity, and soil water characteristics).

Your report should follow this basic outline:

  1. Introduction (optional) (exclude from word count)
  2. Results and discussion (or individual 'Results’ and ‘Discussion’ sections)
  3. Conclusions
  4. References (exclude from word count)

Do not cite your Course notes (for example, LAND2003 or LAND3005). Rather, only cite articles and books from the scientific literature.

Report 3: Fertility Status of Soil

This particular practical report is completed as a group. How the workload is divided amongst your group is up to each group to decide.

Your report should follow this basic outline:

  1. Introduction (optional) (exclude from word count)
  2. Results and discussion (or individual 'Results’ and ‘Discussion’ sections)
  3. Conclusions
  4. References (exclude from word count)

Do not cite your Course notes (for example, LAND2003 or LAND3005). Rather, only cite articles and books from the scientific literature.

Participation in Practical Sessions

The practical exercise is a major part of this course and provides a hands-on understanding of the theoretical knowledge you will gain through the lectures. Participation in the Practicals is compulsory.

Absence from a Practical Session 

If you are unable to complete your timetabled practical session because of circumstances beyond your control (e.g., illness) you must submit a practical absence request immediately accompanied by acceptable supporting documentation.  

 A list of acceptable reasons and required supporting documentation is found at https://my.uq.edu.au/information-and-services/manage-my-program/exams-and-assessment/applying-assessment-extension?p=1#1  

Your request must be submitted prior to or on the day of your missed practical. The submission link can be found in the Learning Resources (Blackboard Original) or Course Resources (Blackboard Ultra) folder in your course Blackboard site.  

Requests without the correct supporting documentation may not be approved. If the reason for your absence is not approved, you will be considered absent from that practical session.  

It is your responsibility to submit an application and provide correct documentation.

If you do not attend the prac and do not have approval, you are unable to obtain marks for the corresponding portions of the prac report.

assessments.task_description:
You are required to review the literature and critically summarise information on one of the two topics listed below. Once you have made your selection, you are then required to prepare an analysis of that topic.

Choose only ONE of the following two topics:

1. Fertilisers, nutrients, and the role of soil nutrient budgeting. There is increasing pressure on soils, not only because we need to produce more food for a growing human population, but also because of competing uses of soils, such as for the production of biofuels.

a. What is a soil nutrient budget and why is it important? AND

b. Giving specific consideration to the nutrient budgets reported for Australia, what are the implications (from both the perspective of the soil and the broader health of the environment and planet) for a positive budget and a negative budget? AND

c. What changes in management can be made where budgets are positive or negative?

2. Global nitrogen cycle. Nitrogen fertilisers are the most commonly applied fertiliser globally. Although our production of food is heavily reliant on these nitrogen fertilisers, the application (and over-application) of these fertilisers causes substantial environmental harm. Give consideration to:

a. How reliant our agricultural systems (and hence the human population) are on nitrogen fertilisers, AND

b. The adverse environmental effects caused by the application (and over-application) of nitrogen fertilisers to soil, including the approaches whereby these adverse impacts could be reduced or avoided in order to ensure the long-term sustainability of the soil-system (ensure your focus remains on soil-based approaches).

Begin by reading all relevant material thoroughly. As you read, make notes of the important ideas and concepts. When writing the analysis, consider the following suggested structure:

  1. Introduction. Describe the overall topic, and summarise your main points that you will then expand in later sections.
  2. Main text (this could be split into different sections). Describe in detail your main information by assessing, reviewing, and summarising the relevant information. Support your evaluation with detailed evidence from the literature. Do not forget to include appropriate references.
  3. Summary. Finish with a summary and an evaluation of your main conclusions.
  4. References. Do not cite your Course notes (for example, LAND2003 or LAND3005). Rather, you must only cite articles and books from the scientific literature.

Length: 2000 words +/- 10% (excluding references and any appendices)
